newsitem.title: USA: Learning Co may buy back stock-executive.
newsitem.headline: Learning Co may buy back stock-executive.

text.p: Executives from The Learning Co told analysts at a Thursday evening conference call that the company may consider buying back some of its stock.

When asked if a stock buyback was being considered -- the share price closed at 10-7/8 on the New York Stock Exchange at nearly five times its projected 1997 earnings -- R. Scott Murray, chief financial officer of the Cambridge-based educational software giant replied, "That is an issue that I'm sure the board will consider at some point in the near future."
First Call Corp's survey of analysts reveals earnings per share expectations of between $1.84 and $2.25 for 1997. The Learning Company reported cash on hand of $110.1 million.

Learning Co President Kevin O'Leary also told the analysts the company would be introducing a line of six branded educational titles that will retail for between $17.99 and $19.95 in the first quarter of 1997. At this price, he expects the titles to be very high volume and impulse sale items.
It will be a new price point for the company, he said, noting its average title retails for about $40.
The Learning Company, Inc develops and markets a family of educational and reference software products that sold through retail outlets, catalogue, on-line and come packaged with home computers.

On-line revenues were "very light" O'Leary said, noting most of the stream came from subscription services to schools and on-line services like America OnLine and Compuserve. "But we have more on-line products coming." he said.

The firm has also expanded its presence in Walmart stores with the huge retailer now carrying 30 titles up from 11 a few months ago. "I think you can assume we're going to be growing that area," O'Leary said.
